description: From Middle English varien, from Old French varier, from Latin variō (“to change, alter, make different”), from varius (“different, various”); see various.

verbs.description: vary (third-person singular simple present varies, present participle varying, simple past and past participle varied)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To change with time or a similar parameter.
examples: He varies his magic tricks so as to minimize the possibility that any given audience member will see the same trick twice.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To institute a change in, from a current state; to modify.
examples: You should vary your diet. Eating just bread will do you harm in the end.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Not to remain constant: to change with time or a similar parameter.
examples: His mood varies by the hour.
The sine function varies between −1 and 1.

entries.meaning: (of the members of a group, intransitive) To display differences.
examples: The sprouting tendency of potatoes varies between cultivars, years and places of growing.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be or act different from the usual.
examples: I'm not comfortable with 3.Nc3 in the Caro-Kann, so I decided to vary and play exd5.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make of different kinds; to make different from one another; to diversity; to variegate.
(transitive, music) To embellish; to change fancifully; to present under new aspects, as of form, key, measure, etc. See variation.
(intransitive, obsolete) To disagree; to be at variance or in dissension.
examples: the rich jewel which we vary for
